docs.lead_paragraph: THE horror began last Mother's Day. Sean Tobin, a young hospital corpsman at the Navy submarine base in Groton, told the police that he grew so frustrated with his 6-week-old son, who was crying and refusing a bottle, that he shook him until his ''neck appeared very loose and his head was rolling around.'' Then he slammed the baby on the couch. Doctors said the baby was unlikely to survive, and the family removed life supports. But the baby, Vincent Tobin, lived. Nearing his first birthday, he is almost totally blind, severely hearing-impaired and unable to crawl or sit up on his own. Cerebral palsy has been diagnosed.

headline.main: Our Towns; After Injury, Added Insult Of Late Aid

docs.abstract: Matthew Purdy Our Towns column discusses plight of 9-month-old Vincent Tobin and his family's battle to receive health insurance from US Navy; Tobin is victim of severe assault by his father Sean, Naval hospital corpsman (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bernae Gunderson, a certified paralegal who lives in St. Paul, is not intimidated by fine print. But she was still puzzled by the mortgage documents she got in May 1998 from the First Alliance Corporation. This did not sound like the affordable home equity loan that she and her husband had been promised. So about 2:30 p.m. on May 26, Mrs. Gunderson called the manager of the mortgage company's local office and asked all the right questions about rates, monthly payments and fees. And she got reassuring answers that confirmed her understanding of the terms of her loan.

headline.main: MORTGAGED LIVES: A special report.; Profiting From Fine Print With Wall Street's Help

docs.abstract: Special report, Mortgaged Lives, notes that scores of consumers have complained to state regulators about First Alliance Corp, national home-equity lender based in Irvine, Calif; over dozen homeowners have already sued; they assert that company has used deceptive sales pitch to lure homeowners into high-cost loans that expose them to threat of foreclosure and financial ruin; company has also been sued by AARP and by regulators in several states; Washington State seeks to suspend it from doing any business there; First Alliance still has some very important supporters, including Wall Street investment banks that help it raise money lent to people; investigation by New York Times and ABC News program 20/20 shows they have pumped hundreds of millions of dollars into First Alliance in recent years, even as lawsuits and state inquiries have raised questions about its practices; company was founded by Brian Chisick and his wife Sarah in 1971; photos (M)

byline.original: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES with LOWELL BERGMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Moderate Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee are drafting their own proposal to offer prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries, as an alternative to President Clinton's plan, and they say their ideas could be a basis for a bipartisan compromise. The proposal, like one advanced by Mr. Clinton last June, would offer drug coverage to all Medicare beneficiaries. But it differs from the Clinton plan in important ways.

headline.main: Democrats Devise an Alternative to Clinton's Drug Plan

docs.abstract: Moderate Democrats on Senate Finance Committee are drafting their own proposal to offer prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries, as alternative to Pres Clinton's plan; say their ideas could be basis for bipartisan compromise; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four major insurance companies have filed a joint lawsuit against a group of doctors -- including one whose license was revoked three years ago -- charging that they sold their names and licenses to chiropractors and other health care workers to steal insurance money. The lawsuit, filed yesterday with the State Supreme Court in Manhattan, describes a complicated scheme to bill insurance companies through 47 fake medical professional corporations, most of which were set up in New York. Under the scheme, the lawsuit says, doctors lent their names to the medical corporations, where people without medical licenses, like chiropractors and physical therapists, would then practice. Those health care workers would then bill for medical services at the rates doctors would charge.

headline.main: Insurers' Suit Accuses Doctors of Fraudulent Billing Scheme

docs.abstract: Four major insurance companies file joint lawsuit against group of doctors, including one whose license was revoked three years ago, charging that they sold their names and licenses to chiropractors and other health care workers; lawsuit, filed in NYS Supreme Court, Manhattan, describes complicated scheme to bill insurance companies through 47 fake medical professional corporations, most of which were set up in New York (M)
